The code is a test file for select_by_intensity function. It creates a Spectrum with mz and intensities arrays, calls select_by_intensity with intensity_to=35.0, expects only peaks with intensity <= 35? Actually intensity_to=35.0 selects peaks with intensity less than or equal to 35? The test expects only one peak: mz 20, intensity 10. Indeed intensities array: [1,10,100,1000]; intensity_to=35 selects peaks with intensity <=35, which includes 1 and 10. But they only keep one peak? Wait they expect only one peak at mz 20 intensity 10. Why not include intensity 1 at mz 10? Possibly because intensity_to selects peaks with intensity >= intensity_to? Actually intensity_to maybe selects peaks with intensity <= intensity_to? But then both 1 and 10 would be kept. However they only keep 10. Maybe the function also selects the most intense peak below threshold? Or maybe intensity_to selects peaks with intensity >= intensity_to? That would keep 100 and 1000 > 35, not 10. So not.

Let's examine: They expect only one peak at mz 20 intensity 10. So maybe the function selects peaks with intensity between intensity_from and intensity_to? But they only passed intensity_to. Maybe default intensity_from is 0? Then select peaks with intensity between 0 and 35 inclusive. That would include 1 and 10. Still two peaks. So why only one? Could be that the function also selects top N peaks? Not in test.

Maybe the function selects peaks with intensity >= intensity_to? That would keep 100 and 1000, not 10. So not.

Maybe the function selects peaks with intensity <= intensity_to and also removes the lowest intensity? Not.
